awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photon-Enabled Atomic Drilling of Graphene for Supercapacitors
awd_abstract_narration:
Supercapacitors have emerged as next-generation high-performance power sources for portable devices used in a wide range of consumer, biomedical, healthcare, and military applications.  It remains a fundamental challenge in supercapacitor design to simultaneously achieve high energy and power densities with a long cycle life.  A porous graphene framework, consisting of a three-dimensional graphene structure containing nano-sized holes and micro-size pores, has emerged as a promising solution to address this challenge due to its superior electrochemical properties.  However, the existing methods for fabricating this graphene framework often rely on thermal chemical etching processes, which suffer from low efficiency and poor controllability due to complex experiments and poor thermal stability of etchants.  This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge for the development of a novel manufacturing strategy using photon-material interactions to realize porous graphene framework fabrication with a high efficiency. This research will have  significant broader impact because of the spillover into many economic sectors because of the potential transformative  performance improvement of supercapacitors.  This project also provides an integrated science and engineering training platform for graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students, with particular emphasis on promoting participation of women and underrepresented students in research.

The goal of this project is to establish a novel photon-enabled atomic drilling process to fabricate porous graphene frameworks toward supercapacitor applications. The photon-enabled atomic drilling approach utilizes photons from a nanosecond pulsed laser to initiate atomic drilling of nanoholes in the graphene basal planes for porous graphene framework fabrication with high efficiency and controllability.  The major research objective is to establish a fundamental understanding of mechanisms involved in the photon-enabled atomic drilling process responsible for the formation of porous graphene frameworks.  A computational model capable of predicting photon-enabled bond excitation and dissociation as affected by the laser processing parameters will be developed.  Microstructure characterization and electrochemical property testing will be conducted to establish the process-structure-property relationship.  This research contributes to advances in photon-based manufacturing technology development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative project, research teams from the University of Nevada, Reno (UNR), Iowa State University (ISU), Arizona State University (ASU), and the University of Nebraska, Lincoln (UNL) developed a photon-enabled atomic drilling (PEAD) process to manufacture holey graphene framework through optimized laser irradiation of graphene flakes in hydrogen peroxide solutions. Specifically, three major research tasks were executed with significant research outcomes. First, the teams developed electron-phonon thermal transport models and applied first-principles photon absorption calculations to rigorously understand laser-material interactions during the PEAD process. Second, the teams experimentally demonstrated the creation of extensive nano-/micro-holes in graphene flakes through the PEAD process; both classical molecular dynamics and deep-neural network-based molecular dynamics were used to reveal the atomic-scale mechanisms of hole formation during the PEAD process. Third, the teams established the structure-property-process relationship of PEAD-fabricated holey graphene frameworks. Notably, the teams fabricated supercapacitors through PEAD and achieved high energy density and power density that are superior to lead-acid batteries, lithium thin-film battery, and commercial activated carbon electrochemical capacitors. 

Supercapacitors have emerged as next-generation high-performance power sources for portable devices used in a wide range of consumer, biomedical, healthcare, and military applications.The holey graphene frameworks developed through the PEAD process in this project meets the requirement as high-performance supercapacitors due to their hierarchical porous structure, light weight, and desirable electrical/mechanical properties. Moreover, the developed PEAD process can be used to manufacture other holey/porous nanomaterials for electrochamical, thermal, and other applications. 

The research results from this project have been implemented into graduate-level and undergraduate-level classes at UNR, ISU, and ASU. Four Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral researcher at UNR have been trained in advanced modeling (first-principles calculations, deep learning, and molecular dynamics) and experimental (materials characterization, laser manufacturing, and device fabrication) through this project. Two Ph.D. students have obtained their Ph.D. degrees through the partial support of this project. 

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2022
Modified by: Yan Wang
